metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, PHP, Python, Bootstrap, Java and XML.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: DSA Maximum Flow
The Maximum Flow Problem
The Maximum Flow problem is about finding the maximum flow through a directed graph, from one place in the graph to another.
content.html: The Maximum Flow problem is about finding the maximum flow through a directed graph, from one place in the graph to another.

content.text: More specifically, the flow comes from a source vertex s s , and ends up in a sink vertex t t , and each edge in the graph is defined with a flow and a capacity, where the capacity is the maximum flow that edge can have.
content.html: More specifically, the flow comes from a source vertex ss, and ends up in a sink vertex tt, and each edge in the graph is defined with a flow and a capacity, where the capacity is the maximum flow that edge can have.

content.text: Max flow: 0
content.html: Max flow: 0

content.text: Finding the maximum flow can be very useful:
content.html: Finding the maximum flow can be very useful:

content.text: Terminology And Concepts
A flow network if often what we call a directed graph with a flow flowing through it.
content.html: A flow network if often what we call a directed graph with a flow flowing through it.

content.text: The capacity c c of an edge tells us how much flow is allowed to flow through that edge.
content.html: The capacity cc of an edge tells us how much flow is allowed to flow through that edge.

content.text: Each edge also has a flow value that tells how much the current flow is in that edge.
content.html: Each edge also has a flow value that tells how much the current flow is in that edge.

content.text: The edge in the image above v 1 → v 2 v 1 → v 2 , going from vertex v 1 v 1 to vertex v 2 v 2 , has its flow and capacity described as 0/7 , which means the flow is 0 , and the capacity is 7 . So the flow in this edge can be increased up to 7, but not more.
content.html: The edge in the image above v1→v2v1→v2, going from vertex v1v1 to vertex v2v2, has its flow and capacity described as 0/7, which means the flow is 0, and the capacity is 7. So the flow in this edge can be increased up to 7, but not more.

content.text: In its simplest form, flow network has one source vertex s s where the flow comes out, and one sink vertex t t where the flow goes in. The other vertices just have flow passing through them.
content.html: In its simplest form, flow network has one source vertex ss where the flow comes out, and one sink vertex tt where the flow goes in. The other vertices just have flow passing through them.

content.text: For all vertices except s s and t t , there is a conservation of flow , which means that the same amount of flow that goes into a vertex, must also come out of it.
content.html: For all vertices except ss and tt, there is a conservation of flow, which means that the same amount of flow that goes into a vertex, must also come out of it.

content.text: The maximum flow is found by algorithms such as Ford-Fulkerson, or Edmonds-Karp, by sending more and more flow through the edges in the flow network until the capacity of the edges are such that no more flow can be sent through. Such a path where more flow can be sent through is called an augmented path .
content.html: The maximum flow is found by algorithms such as Ford-Fulkerson, or Edmonds-Karp, by sending more and more flow through the edges in the flow network until the capacity of the edges are such that no more flow can be sent through. Such a path where more flow can be sent through is called an augmented path.

content.text: The Ford-Fulkerson and Edmonds-Karp algorithms are implemented using something called a residual network . This will be explained in more detail on the next pages.
content.html: The Ford-Fulkerson and Edmonds-Karp algorithms are implemented using something called a residual network. This will be explained in more detail on the next pages.

content.text: The residual network is set up with the residual capacities on each edge, where the residual capacity of an edge is the capacity on that edge, minus the flow. So when flow is increased in a an edge, the residual capacity is decreased with the same amount.
content.html: The residual network is set up with the residual capacities on each edge, where the residual capacity of an edge is the capacity on that edge, minus the flow. So when flow is increased in a an edge, the residual capacity is decreased with the same amount.

content.text: For each edge in the residual network, there is also a reversed edge that points in the opposite direction of the original edge. The residual capacity of a reversed edge is the flow of the original edge. Reversed edges are important for sending flow back on an edge as part of the maximum flow algorithms.
content.html: For each edge in the residual network, there is also a reversed edge that points in the opposite direction of the original edge. The residual capacity of a reversed edge is the flow of the original edge. Reversed edges are important for sending flow back on an edge as part of the maximum flow algorithms.

content.text: The image below shows the reversed edges in the graph from the simulation at the top of this page. Each reversed edge points in the opposite direction, and because there is no flow in the graph to begin with, the residual capacities for the reversed edges are 0.
content.html: The image below shows the reversed edges in the graph from the simulation at the top of this page. Each reversed edge points in the opposite direction, and because there is no flow in the graph to begin with, the residual capacities for the reversed edges are 0.

content.text: Some of these concepts, like the residual network and the reversed edge, can be hard to understand. That is why these concepts are explained more in detail, and with examples, on the next two pages.
content.html: Some of these concepts, like the residual network and the reversed edge, can be hard to understand. That is why these concepts are explained more in detail, and with examples, on the next two pages.

content.text: When the maximum flow is found, we get a value for how much flow can be sent through the flow network in total.
content.html: When the maximum flow is found, we get a value for how much flow can be sent through the flow network in total.

content.text: Multiple Source and Sink Vertices
The Ford-Fulkerson and Edmonds-Karp algorithms expects one source vertex and one sink vertex to be able to find the maximum flow.
content.html: The Ford-Fulkerson and Edmonds-Karp algorithms expects one source vertex and one sink vertex to be able to find the maximum flow.

content.text: If the graph has more than one source vertex, or more than one sink vertex, the graph should be modified to find the maximum flow.
content.html: If the graph has more than one source vertex, or more than one sink vertex, the graph should be modified to find the maximum flow.

content.text: To modify the graph so that you can run the Ford-Fulkerson or Edmonds-Karp algorithm on it, create an extra super-source vertex if you have multiple source vertices, and create an extra super-sink vertex if you have multiple sink-vertices.
content.html: To modify the graph so that you can run the Ford-Fulkerson or Edmonds-Karp algorithm on it, create an extra super-source vertex if you have multiple source vertices, and create an extra super-sink vertex if you have multiple sink-vertices.

content.text: From the super-source vertex, create edges to the original source vertices, with infinite capacities. And create edges from the sink vertices to the super-sink vertex similarly, with infinite capacities.
content.html: From the super-source vertex, create edges to the original source vertices, with infinite capacities. And create edges from the sink vertices to the super-sink vertex similarly, with infinite capacities.

content.text: The image below shows such a graph with two sources s 1 s 1 and s 2 s 2 , and three sinks t 1 t 1 , t 2 t 2 , and t 3 t 3 .
content.html: The image below shows such a graph with two sources s1s1 and s2s2, and three sinks t1t1, t2t2, and t3t3.

content.text: To run Ford-Fulkerson or Edmonds-Karp on this graph, a super source S S is created with edges with infinite capacities to the original source nodes, and a super sink T T is created with edges with infinite capacities to it from the original sinks.
content.html: To run Ford-Fulkerson or Edmonds-Karp on this graph, a super source SS is created with edges with infinite capacities to the original source nodes, and a super sink TT is created with edges with infinite capacities to it from the original sinks.

content.text: The Ford-Fulkerson or Edmonds-Karp algorithm is now able to find maximum flow in a graph with multiple source and sink vertices, by going from the super source S S , to the super sink T T .
content.html: The Ford-Fulkerson or Edmonds-Karp algorithm is now able to find maximum flow in a graph with multiple source and sink vertices, by going from the super source SS, to the super sink TT.

content.text: The Max-flow Min-cut Theorem
To understand what this theorem says we first need to know what a cut is.
content.html: To understand what this theorem says we first need to know what a cut is.

content.text: We create two sets of vertices: one with only the source vertex inside it called "S", and one with all the other vertices inside it (including the sink vertex) called "T".
content.html: We create two sets of vertices: one with only the source vertex inside it called "S", and one with all the other vertices inside it (including the sink vertex) called "T".

content.text: Now, starting in the source vertex, we can choose to expand set S by including adjacent vertices, and continue to include adjacent vertices as much as we want as long as we do not include the sink vertex.
content.html: Now, starting in the source vertex, we can choose to expand set S by including adjacent vertices, and continue to include adjacent vertices as much as we want as long as we do not include the sink vertex.

content.text: Expanding set S will shrink set T, because any vertex belongs either to set S or set T.
content.html: Expanding set S will shrink set T, because any vertex belongs either to set S or set T.

content.text: In such a setup, with any vertex belonging to either set S or set T, there is a "cut" between the sets. The cut consists of all the edges stretching from set S to set T.
content.html: In such a setup, with any vertex belonging to either set S or set T, there is a "cut" between the sets. The cut consists of all the edges stretching from set S to set T.

content.text: If we add all the capacities from edges going from set S to set T, we get the capacity of the cut, which is the total possible flow from source to sink in this cut.
content.html: If we add all the capacities from edges going from set S to set T, we get the capacity of the cut, which is the total possible flow from source to sink in this cut.

content.text: The minimum cut is the cut we can make with the lowest total capacity, which will be the bottleneck.
content.html: The minimum cut is the cut we can make with the lowest total capacity, which will be the bottleneck.

content.text: In the image below, three different cuts are done in the graph from the simulation in the top of this page.
content.html: In the image below, three different cuts are done in the graph from the simulation in the top of this page.

content.text: Cut A: This cut has vertices s s and v 1 v 1 in set S, and the other vertices are in set T. The total capacity of the edges leaving set S in this cut, from sink to source, is 3+4+7=14. We are not adding the capacity from edge v 2 → v 1 v 2 → v 1 , because this edge goes in the opposite direction, from sink to source. So the maximum possible flow across cut A is 14.
content.html: Cut A: This cut has vertices ss and v1v1 in set S, and the other vertices are in set T. The total capacity of the edges leaving set S in this cut, from sink to source, is 3+4+7=14. We are not adding the capacity from edge v2→v1v2→v1, because this edge goes in the opposite direction, from sink to source. So the maximum possible flow across cut A is 14.

content.text: Cut B: The maximum possible flow is 3+4+3=10 across cut B.
content.html: Cut B: The maximum possible flow is 3+4+3=10 across cut B.

content.text: Cut C: The maximum possible flow is 2+6=8 across cut C. If we checked all other cuts in the graph, we would not find a cut with a lower total capacity. This is the minimum cut. Have you run the simulation finding the maximum flow in the top of this page? Then you also know that 8 is the maximum flow, which is exactly what the max-flow min-cut theorem says.
content.html: Cut C: The maximum possible flow is 2+6=8 across cut C. If we checked all other cuts in the graph, we would not find a cut with a lower total capacity. This is the minimum cut. Have you run the simulation finding the maximum flow in the top of this page? Then you also know that 8 is the maximum flow, which is exactly what the max-flow min-cut theorem says.

content.text: The max-flow min-cut theorem says that finding the minimum cut in a graph, is the same as finding the maximum flow, because the value of the minimum cut will be the same value as the maximum flow.
content.html: The max-flow min-cut theorem says that finding the minimum cut in a graph, is the same as finding the maximum flow, because the value of the minimum cut will be the same value as the maximum flow.

content.text: Practical Implications of The Max-flow Min-cut Theorem
Finding the maximum flow in a graph using an algorithm like Ford-Fulkerson also helps us to understand where the minimum cut is: The minimum cut will be where the edges have reached full capacity.
content.html: Finding the maximum flow in a graph using an algorithm like Ford-Fulkerson also helps us to understand where the minimum cut is: The minimum cut will be where the edges have reached full capacity.

content.text: The minimum cut will be where the bottleneck is, so if we want to increase flow beyond the maximum limit, which is often the case in practical situations, we now know which edges in the graph that needs to be modified to increase the overall flow.
content.html: The minimum cut will be where the bottleneck is, so if we want to increase flow beyond the maximum limit, which is often the case in practical situations, we now know which edges in the graph that needs to be modified to increase the overall flow.

content.text: Modifying edges in the minimum cut to allow more flow can be very useful in many situations:
content.html: Modifying edges in the minimum cut to allow more flow can be very useful in many situations:

content.text: So using maximum flow algorithms to find the minimum cut, helps us to understand where the system can be modified to allow an even higher throughput.
content.html: So using maximum flow algorithms to find the minimum cut, helps us to understand where the system can be modified to allow an even higher throughput.

content.text: The Maximum Flow Problem Described Mathematically
The maximum flow problem is not just a topic in Computer Science, it is also a type of Mathematical Optimization, that belongs to the field of Mathematics.
content.html: The maximum flow problem is not just a topic in Computer Science, it is also a type of Mathematical Optimization, that belongs to the field of Mathematics.

content.text: In case you want to understand this better mathematically, the maximum flow problem is described in mathematical terms below.
content.html: In case you want to understand this better mathematically, the maximum flow problem is described in mathematical terms below.

content.text: All edges ( E E ) in the graph, going from a vertex ( u u ) to a vertex ( v v ), have a flow ( f f ) that is less than, or equal to, the capacity ( c c ) of that edge:
content.html: All edges (EE) in the graph, going from a vertex (uu) to a vertex (vv), have a flow (ff) that is less than, or equal to, the capacity (cc) of that edge:

content.text: ∀ ( u , v ) ∈ E : f ( u , v ) ≤ c ( u , v ) ∀ ( u , v ) ∈ E : f ( u , v ) ≤ c ( u , v )
content.html: ∀(u,v)∈E:f(u,v)≤c(u,v)∀(u,v)∈E:f(u,v)≤c(u,v)

content.text: This basically just means that the flow in an edge is limited by the capacity in that edge.
content.html: This basically just means that the flow in an edge is limited by the capacity in that edge.

content.text: Also, for all edges ( E E ), a flow in one direction from u u to v v is the same as having a negative flow in the reverse direction, from v v to u u :
content.html: Also, for all edges (EE), a flow in one direction from uu to vv is the same as having a negative flow in the reverse direction, from vv to uu:
∀(u,v)∈E:f(u,v)=−f(v,u)∀(u,v)∈E:f(u,v)=−f(v,u)

content.text: And the expression below states that conservation of flow is kept for all vertices ( u u ) except for the source vertex ( s s ) and for the sink vertex ( t t ):
content.html: And the expression below states that conservation of flow is kept for all vertices (uu) except for the source vertex (ss) and for the sink vertex (tt):
∀u∈V∖{s,t}⇒∑w∈Vf(u,w)=0∀u∈V∖{s,t}⇒∑w∈Vf(u,w)=0

content.text: This just means that the amount of flow going into a vertex, is the same amount of flow that comes out of that vertex (except for the source and sink vertices).
content.html: This just means that the amount of flow going into a vertex, is the same amount of flow that comes out of that vertex (except for the source and sink vertices).

content.text: And at last, all flow leaving the source vertex s s , must end up in the sink vertex t t :
content.html: And at last, all flow leaving the source vertex ss, must end up in the sink vertex tt:

content.text: ∑ ( s , u ) ∈ E f ( s , u ) = ∑ ( v , t ) ∈ E f ( v , t ) ∑ ( s , u ) ∈ E f ( s , u ) = ∑ ( v , t ) ∈ E f ( v , t )
content.html: ∑(s,u)∈Ef(s,u)=∑(v,t)∈Ef(v,t)∑(s,u)∈Ef(s,u)=∑(v,t)∈Ef(v,t)

content.text: The equation above states that adding all flow going out on edges from the source vertex will give us the same sum as adding the flow in all edges going into the sink vertex.
content.html: The equation above states that adding all flow going out on edges from the source vertex will give us the same sum as adding the flow in all edges going into the sink vertex.
